case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P. v. Lab Manmohan Das

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 512 of 1964 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 512 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated December 23, 1960 of the Allahabad High Court in Income-tax Misc. Case No. 475 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated December 23, 1960 of the Allahabad High Court in Income-tax Misc. Case No. 475 of 1954.

facts.text: Under an agreement dated January 2, 1931, Lab Manmohan Das (assessee) was appointed Treasurer of the Allahabad Bank Ltd. in respect of certain Branches, Sub-Agencies and Pay Offices.

anchor.surface_text: Under an agreement dated January 2, 1931, Lab Manmohan Das-hereinafter called the assessee-was appointed Treasurer of the Allahabad Bank Ltd. in respect of certain Branches, Sub-Agencies and Pay Offices.

facts.text: The assessee was assessed to income-tax as representing his Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee was assessed to income-tax as representing his Hindu undivided family, and the income received by the assessee under the terms of the agreement with the Allahabad Bank, was treated as income of the Hindu undivided family.

facts.text: Income received by the assessee under the agreement with Allahabad Bank was treated as income of the Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: and the income received by the assessee under the terms of the agreement with the Allahabad Bank, was treated as income of the Hindu undivided family.

facts.text: In the previous year corresponding to assessment year 1950-51, the assessee suffered a net loss of Rs. 38,027 as Treasurer.

anchor.surface_text: In the previous year companyresponding to the assessment year 1950-51 the assessee in performing his duties as a Treasurer suffered a net loss of Rs. 38,027.

facts.text: For assessment year 1951-52, profit and loss account showed Rs. 73,815 as receipts.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1951-52, the profit and loss account of the assesses showed Rs. 73,815 as receipts, against which were debited outgoings amounting to Rs. 39,370

facts.text: Outgoings amounted to Rs. 39,370 including Rs. 20,000 loss from misappropriation by Assistant Cashier at Patna Branch.

anchor.surface_text: against which were debited outgoings amounting to Rs. 39,370 which included Rs. 20,000 being the loss suffered by the assessee as Treasurer of the Patna Branch of the Allahabad Bank arising from misappropriation by an Assistant Cashier.

facts.text: Net profit of Rs. 34,445 for 1951-52.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer refused to allow the loss suffered in the previous year to be set off against the net profit of Rs. 34,445

facts.text: Income-tax Officer refused to allow the loss of previous year to be set off and brought Rs. 34,445 to tax as remuneration.

anchor.surface_text: and brought that amount of profit to tax as remuneration received by the assessee as Treasurer of the Allahabad Bank.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed the ITO's order.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Income- tax Officer was companyflrmed in appeal by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held remuneration was income from profession or vocation u/s 10 and loss set off allowed.

anchor.surface_text: The 5 33 Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held that the remuneration received by the assessee as Treasurer of the Allahabad Bank was income arising from pursuit of a profession or vocation within the meaning of s. 10 of the Act and the loss suffered during the preceding year was liable to be set off

facts.text: At instance of Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P., questions referred to Allahabad High Court u/s 66(1) of 1922 Act.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P., the following questions were referred to the High Court of Allahabad under s. 66 1  of the Income-tax Act, 1922

facts.text: High Court held remuneration taxed u/s 10 and set off of 1950-51 loss against 1951-52 profit allowed.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the remuneration received by the from the Allahabad Bank was income liable to be taxed under s. 10 of the Income-tax Act, and that the assessee companyld claim to set off the loss companyputed in the assessment year 1950-51 against the profit in the subsequent year.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court preferred by Commissioner with certificate from High Court.

anchor.surface_text: With certificate granted by the High Court, this appeal has been preferred by the Commissioner of Income-tax.

facts.text: For 1950-51, ITO declared loss could not be carried forward u/s 24 as not business loss.

anchor.surface_text: In making his order of assessment for the year 1950-51 the Income-tax Officer declared that the loss companyputed in that year companyld number be carried forward to the next year under s 24 2  of the Income-tax Act, as it was number a business loss.

facts.text: Agreement remuneration: monthly allowance total Rs. 2,250 plus Rs. 350 travelling expenses.

anchor.surface_text: The remuneration of the. Treasurer shall be a monthly allowance for each of the Branches, SubAgencies and Pay Offices the total of such monthly allowance to be Rs. 2,250  Rupees two thousand two hundred and fifty  plus Rs. 350  Rupees three hundred fifty  for travelling expenses.

facts.text: Treasurer appoints Indian staff at salaries paid by Bank, with Bank approval; responsible for their acts.

anchor.surface_text: The Treasurer shall with the approval of the Bank appoint at adequate salaries to be paid by the Bank all the Indian staff as may be company- sidered sufficient by the Bank for the business of the Cash Department of the Banks Branches, Sub-Agencies and Pay Offices . . .

facts.text: Agreement terminable by 3 months notice by either party; survives death binding heirs.

anchor.surface_text: The Treasurers employment may be determined at any time by either party giving to the other three calendar months written numberice to that effect, and in case of the Treasurers death, this agreement as regards the Treasurers liabilities and obligations for the staff and other persons shall remain in force

facts.text: Misappropriation by Assistant Cashier at Patna Branch caused Rs. 20,000 loss.

anchor.surface_text: which included Rs. 20,000 being the loss suffered by the assessee as Treasurer of the Patna Branch of the Allahabad Bank arising from misappropriation by an Assistant Cashier.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Treasurer not servant, remuneration under s.10 as vocation, set off allowed.

anchor.surface_text: The remuneration must therefore be companyputed under s. IO of the Income-tax Act and loss of profit suffered in that vocation in any year may be carried forward to the next year and be set off against the profit of the succeeding year.

facts.text: Branches include Calcutta, Lahore, Lucknow, Patna, Amritsar, Benaras, Secunderabad.

anchor.surface_text: The Treasurer is under the agreement responsible for the acts of the Indian staff at the Branches, SubAgencies and Pay. Offices as far apart as Calcutta, Lahore, Lucknow, Patna, Amritsar, Benaras and Secunderabad.

issues.text: Whether on a true interpretation of the deed of agreement dated 2nd January, 1931, appointing the assessee as Treasurer of the Allahabad Bank Limited, income earned by the assessee from his activities as such Treasurer fell to be computed under Section 10 of the Act or Section 7 or Section 12 of the Income-tax Act ?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on a true interpretation of the deed of agreement dated 2nd January, 1931, appointing the assessee as Treasurer of the Allahabad Bank Limited, income earned by the assessee from his activities as such Treasurer fell to be computed under Section 10 of the Act or Section 7 or

issues.text: If the answer to this question is that such income is liable to be computed under Section 10 of the Act, Whether the assessee could claim a set off of the loss suffered by him in the preceding year 1950-51 against his profits in the year under consideration, i.e., 1951-52 having failed to prefer an appeal against the refusal by the Income-tax Officer making the assessment for the year 1950-51 to allow the assessee to carry forward the loss under Section 24 2  of the Act ?

anchor.surface_text: If the answer to this question is that such income is liable to be computed under Section 10 of the Act, Whether the assessee could claim a set off of the loss suffered by him in the preceding year 1950-51 against his profits in the year under consideration, i.e., 1951-52 having failed to prefer an appeal against the refusal by the Income-tax Officer making

issues.text: Whether under the terms of the agreement the assessee was carrying on a business, profession or vocation, or was a servant of the Bank such that remuneration is computed under s.7

anchor.surface_text: The answer to the first question depends upon the true interpretation of the terms of the agreement between the Allahabad Bank and the assessee If under the terms of the agreement it is found that the assessee was carrying on a business, profession or vocation, the assessee would be entitled to carry forward the loss suffered therein and set it off against the profits in the subsequent year of the same business, profession or vocation under s. 24 2 . If the remuneration was received by the assessee as a servant of the Bank, and on that account has to be computed under s. 7 of the Act, the right to set off the loss cannot be claimed under s. 24 2 .

issues.text: Whether the Income-tax Officer's decision in the previous year under s.24(3) that the loss cannot be carried forward is binding on the assessee in the subsequent year

anchor.surface_text: A decision recorded by the Income-tax Officer who computes the loss in the previous year under s. 24 3  that the loss cannot be set off against the income of the subsequent year is not binding on the assessee.

issues.text: Whether the occupation of the Treasurer is a profession, business or vocation under s.10

anchor.surface_text: It is difficult to regard the occupation of the Treasurer under the agreement as a profession, for a profession involves occupation requiring purely intellectual or manual skill... Occupation of a Treasurer is not one of the recognized professions, nor can it be said that it partakes of the character of a business or trade... the assessee may be regarded as following a vocation.

issues.text: Whether there is a master-servant relationship or right of control by the Bank over the Treasurer

anchor.surface_text: The test which is uniformly applied in order to determine the relationship is the existence of a right of control in respect of the manner in which the work is to be done... There is however no covenant which authorises the Bank to control the Treasurer in the due performance of duties undertaken by him under the terms of the agreement.

anchor.surface_text: In making his order of assessment for the year 1950-51 the Income-tax Officer declared that the loss computed in that year could not be carried forward to the next year under s 24 2  of the Income-tax Act, as it was not a business loss.

arguments.court_reasoning: Contracts not identical; no control or supervision by Bank in this case; distinguished on terms

arguments.claim: s.24(2) statutory right to carry forward loss from business/profession/vocation determined in subsequent year

anchor.surface_text: Section 24 2 confers a statutory right subject to certain conditions which are not material upon the assessee who sustains a loss of profits in any year in any business, profession or vocation to carry forward the loss as is not set off under sub-s 1 to the following year, and to set it off against his profits

anchor.surface_text: A decision recorded by the Income-tax Officer who computes the loss in the previous year under s. 24 3 that the loss cannot be set off against the income of the subsequent year is not binding on the assessee.

arguments.court_reasoning: Applied from Dharangadhara Chemical Works; no covenant authorizing Bank control

arguments.claim: In Piyare Lal, Treasurer servant due to Bank's control and summary dismissal power
arguments.court_reasoning: No such control or summary termination in present agreement

arguments.claim: Remuneration computed under s.10; loss carry forward and set-off allowed

anchor.surface_text: The remuneration must therefore be computed under s. IO of the Income-tax Act and loss of profit suffered in that vocation in any year may be carried forward to the next year and be set off against the profit of the succeeding year.

holdings.text: A decision recorded by the Income-tax Officer who computes the loss in the previous year under s. 24(3) that the loss cannot be set off against the income of the subsequent year is not binding on the assessee; the right under s.24(2) is to be determined by the ITO in the subsequent assessment year.

anchor.surface_text: A decision recorded by the Income-tax Officer who computes the loss in the previous year under s. 24 3  that the loss cannot be set off against the income of the subsequent year is number binding on the assessee. The answer to the first question depends upon the true interpretation of the terms of the agreem

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.24(2) confers statutory right subject to conditions; determination of carry forward and set-off made afresh by ITO assessing subsequent year regardless of prior s.24(3) notification.

holdings.text: The Treasurer was not a servant of the Allahabad Bank under the terms of the agreement dated January 2, 1931, and the remuneration received by him was not salaries within the meaning of s. 7 of the Income-tax Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No right of control by Bank over manner of performance; contract for service (independent contractor) not of service (employee); distinguished Shivnandan Sharma and Piyare Lal precedents on differing terms.

holdings.text: The assessee's occupation as Treasurer constitutes a vocation; remuneration computed under s.10 of the Income-tax Act and loss from that vocation in prior year may be carried forward and set off against subsequent year profits.

anchor.surface_text: The remuneration must therefore be computed under s. IO of the Income-tax Act and loss of profit suffered in that vocation in any year may be carried forward to the next year and be set off against the profit of the succeeding year.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not profession (no pure intellectual skill) or business/trade; involves skill, judgment, supervision, responsibility and guarantee against loss; taxable as vocation profits u/s 10 allowing s.24(2) set-off.

holdings.text: Absence of covenant authorising Bank control over Treasurer's performance of duties; right of control test not satisfied, no master-servant relationship.

anchor.surface_text: The test which is uniformly applied in order to determine the relationship is the existence of a right of control in respect of the manner in which the work is to be done... There is however no covenant which authorises the Bank to control the Treasurer in the due performance of duties undertaken by him under the terms of the agreement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied settled control test from Dharangadhara Chemical Works; Bank pays staff but Treasurer controls, appoints, supervises; onerous liabilities without Bank's manner control.

holdings.text: Occupation of Treasurer is a vocation, not profession or business.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Profession requires intellectual/manual skill; not recognized profession; not business/trade character; supervisory skill, judgment, guarantee against loss qualify as vocation.

precedents.citation: Dharangadhara Chemical Works Ltd. v. State of Saurashtra 1

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Dharangadhara Chemical Works Ltd. v. State of Saurashtra 1 observed The principles according to which the relationship -as between employer and employee or master and servant has got to be determined are well settled. The test which is uniformly applied in order to determine the relationship is the existence of a right of control in res- pect of the manner in which the work is to be done.

precedents.case_name: Dharangadhara Chemical Works Ltd. v. State of Saurashtra
precedents.cited_proposition: Test of control to determine master-servant relationship: existence of right of control over manner of work; distinction between contract for service and contract of service; nature of control varies by business
precedents.cited_holding: The test which is uniformly applied in order to determine the relationship is the existence of a right of control in respect of the manner in which the work is to be done.

precedents.citation: Simons v. Health Laundry Company- 1910 1 B. 543

anchor.surface_text: or. to use the words of Fletcher Moulton, L.J., at page 549 in Simons v. Health Laundry Company- 1910 1 B. 543 . . . it is impossible to lay down any rule of law distinguishing the one from the other. It is a question of fact to be decided by all the circumstances of the case.

precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between contract of service and independent contractor is a question of fact based on degree of control and circumstances
precedents.cited_holding: it is impossible to lay down any rule of law distinguishing the one from the other. It is a question of fact to be decided by all the circumstances of the case.

precedents.citation: Shivnandan Sharma v. The Punjab National Bank Ltd. 1

anchor.surface_text: But Mr. Sastri on behalf of the Revenue contended relying upon Shivnandan Sharma v. The Punjab National Bank Ltd. 1  and Piyare Lal Adishawar Lal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Delhi 2 , that under the contracts substantially similar to the contract in this case, Treasurers were held merely to be servants of the Banks, business whereof they attended.

precedents.case_name: Shivnandan Sharma v. The Punjab National Bank Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Treasurer appointed to supervise Cash Department of Bank is servant of the Bank and not independent contractor
precedents.cited_holding: under the terms of the agreement between the Treasurer and the Bank, the Treasurer was the servant of the Bank and not an independent contractor

precedents.citation: Piyare Lal Adishawar Lal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Delhi 2

anchor.surface_text: But Mr. Sastri on behalf of the Revenue contended relying upon Shivnandan Sharma v. The Punjab National Bank Ltd. 1  and Piyare Lal Adishawar Lal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Delhi 2 , that under the contracts substantially similar to the contract in this case, Treasurers were held merely to be servants of the Banks, business whereof they attended.

precedents.case_name: Piyare Lal Adishawar Lal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Delhi
precedents.cited_proposition: Treasurer of Bank is servant, remuneration is salary under s.7 not business income under s.10
precedents.cited_holding: the Treasurer was a servant of the Bank and the emoluments received by the Treasurer were in the nature of salary and assessable under S. 7 of the Income-tax Act and not profits and gains of business under S. 10

anchor.surface_text: Taking into consideration the nature of the duties performed, and the obligations undertaken, together with the right to remuneration subject to compensation for loss arising to the Bank from his own acts and omissions or of the servants introduced by him into the business of the Bank, the assessee may be regarded as following a vocation. The remuneration must therefore be computed under s. 10 of the Income-tax Act and loss of profit suffered in that vocation in any year may be carried forward to the next year and be set off against the profit of the succeeding year.

outcome.relief_summary: Remuneration received by assessee as Treasurer computed under Section 10 of Income-tax Act as income from vocation; entitled to carry forward and set off loss from previous year (1950-51) against profits of subsequent year (1951-52).

anchor.surface_text: Taking into consideration the nature of the duties performed, and the obligations undertaken, together with the right to remuneration subject to compensation for loss arising to the Bank from his own acts and omissions or of the servants introduced by him into the business of the Bank, the assessee may be regarded as following a vocation. The remuneration must therefore be computed under s. 10 of the Income-tax Act and loss of profit suffered in that vocation in any year may be carried forward to the next year and be set off against the profit of the succeeding year.

anchor.surface_text: The test which is uniformly applied in order to determine the relationship is the existence of a right of control in respect of the manner in which the work is to be done... There is however no covenant which authorises the Bank to control the Treasurer in the due performance of duties undertaken by him under the terms of the agreement.

Taking into consideration the nature of the duties performed, and the obligations undertaken, together with the right to remuneration subject to compensation for loss arising to the Bank from his own acts and omissions or of the servants introduced by him into the business of the Bank, the assessee may be regarded as following a vocation. The remuneration must therefore be computed under s. 10 of the Income-tax Act and loss of profit suffered in that vocation in any year may be carried forward to the next year and be set off against the profit of the succeeding year.
